Bottle:  Pours a clear apple juice color with a small white head.  Aroma is pungent with hops, florals and dirty dandelions.  Some light sweetness in the background.  Definitely an earthy, hoppy smell.  Tastes a little bit smooth and sweet up front, as if the hops have faded and the malts will be taking over.  Florals, citrus, and tropical fruity hops come through stronger in the tail, leaving a lingering floral bitter trail.  I can tell there is something different about this hop variety, but maybe its the rye?  Really easy drinking.

Bottle spit among friends produced a smaller white head than expected that went off to nothing. it has a somewhat cloudy yellow in color body to it.

I will say I wasnt to much impressed with the new hop variety. I didnt get the grapefruit aroma the touted on the bottle but more of grassy earthy hops to it. It was nice but having tried this right after their Duet It was a little underwhelming.
The flavor was kind of a nice for Rye. PA and I will say one of the better of that hybrid that I have tasted. It had a good balance of pepper and hop to it and it finished rather dry in the mouth. The feel was light with somewhat a lack of carbonation for me. I think this brew needed more.

I finished the glass easily. its a ok beer but I have had better in this Hybrid of a style.

Edit.. after looking at others reviews I would be up to try this one again to see if it wasnt a fluke or a bad bottle

Bottle shared by Mark. Poured a clear medium orange color with a white head. Smelled mostly of grape candy and pale malt. There were also whiffs of black pepper and pine. Odd. Medium bodied and slightly sweet with mild bitterness. Tasted of biscuity malt, grape candy, and dilute vodka. Again, odd.

Tasted from 22oz bottle.  Pours pale orange with a thick and frothy white head that slowly recedes to heavy lace.  Nose of lemon, pineapple and other tropical fruits, hemp, and I think that the rye is adding a dimension that I am not used to smelling.  The pineapple flavor really comes through on the palate with lemon and even some red fruits.  The rye is also a flavor that I recognize on the palate as hard as it was for me to discern on the nose.  This is full bodied, as there is something almost creamy with average carbonation and a long, beautiful finish dominated by pineapple and rye.  This beer is ridiculously drinkable with no alcohol burn.

Awesomely pale, basically gold. Could pass for a pils. One of these days a local micro will figure out this is the way to do an IPA. Points for hop intensity, but its pretty weird. Ink, lemon balm and a serious new sneaker rubberiness which I have gotten from Simcoe before and do not like at all. Doesnt taste like Nelson Sauvin as I know it at all, but nor does it taste like a classic west coast IPA. Distinct retronasal strawberries - hops or yeast I wonder? Odd mouthfeel too - chalky and rubbery where youd expect a hit of lively hop acid. Malt is effectively inconsequential but its not out of balance so doing its job perfectly I suppose. Perfectly well put together, but the hop character is just all over the place. That said, I had no problem polishing it off rather quickly.
sampled at Andy and Maxs fantasy tasting - super hoppy, pine and floral. Sweet caramel balanced by a birllian hoppy spice, pepper, pineapple. Very aroumatic and herbal with a touch of funk. Nice!

Bottle from snojerk321. Pours orange with whispy white head. Aroma is dominated by citrus and dried orange peel. That continues in the flavor, which also has a light caramel touch and lots of hop oils. Lingering finish.

From stefanje via trade.  Poured a slightly hazy copper color with a one-finger tall white head and nice lacing.  The aroma was mostly pine and floral hops.  Sweet, biscuity malts cut through the pine and floral in the flavor.  Thin to medium in body with a clean finish.  Kind of one-dimensional but not bad.

Bottle at Fantasy Tasting.  Pale yellow with nice head.  Super citrus lemon pastry yeasty aroma.  Lemony pineapple citrus fruity sweetness with piney citrus dry finish.  Soft effervescent palate.  Awesome.

bottle thanks to Deadgirl!  Pours bright orange with a medium white head.  Aroma is amazing.  Strong orange and citrus skin notes with a little dank aroma.  Flavor is creamy rich pale and biscuit malts with a touch of the rye and a strong pounding of citrus and earthy hops rounding out.  Nicely balanced and delicious.

Small offwhite head with fair retention and a coating lace. Hazy gold color, ugly. Nose is nice. Tropical, fruity with some bubblegum notes, alittle musty. Body is medium, soft carbonation, lightly resiny and a touch juicey. Fruity hoppy flavors that are kinda tired. Light pale malt notes, hint of caramel,tad skunky, sweaty notes. Fairl;y dry finish, tame bitterness. Bomber from dirtymartini.

22oz bottle. Rating #175. Straw/gold color with a big bubbly white head with a little lacing. Interesting aroma, can get some of the rye coming through and a light fruitiness and a little citrus. Very silky, more light fruit and citrus and very drinkable, damn fine stuff. (1211)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: I appreciate the understated bitterness of this IPA and it was reminicent of the Mikkeller, anlthough yes I did not do a vertical at this time.  Pleasant appearance and aroma, like a white wine and fruity.  I believe I enjoyed this attribute more so in the Mikkeller.  I liked the rye edge.  Very drinkable.Bomber .

2010 Bottle - Thanks stefanje!!! Pours a cloudy lt orange with a large frothy off white head...aroma is dank citrus fruits and some slight garlic, pineapple and dough...flavour is similarly dank hoppy, oily hop resin, raw grain and toast...finish is dry and bitter like an IPA should be!

The aroma is caramel, citrus, peach, grapes, very nice.  The flavor is the same, caramel, citrus/grapefruit, other light fruits.  The appearance is an orange yellow color, white head.  The finish is a grapefruit bitterness.  Decent IPA.

22oz bottle. Amazing aroma of spicy hops jumps out of the glass. Simply fantastic and bright hop aroma. The hop flavor in the taste is more subdued, and the dominating trait is a lightly resinous cereal malt sweetness with the rye sticking out. Taste is still very nice, just doesnt live up to the promise from the aroma.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2012 Bottle at Andy and Maxs fantasy tasting.  Pours a lightly hazed light gold with a small white head.  Gorgeous hop aromas, citrus, pineapple, mango, tropical fruit, herbal.  Hop candy.  Just want to smell this all day.  Medium bodied, almost fried food flavors in there, somewhat odd greasy feel.  Light caramel and malt, somewhat odd.  Finishes with a soft slow grapefruit bitterness.  Not as good as the nose, but interesting. 

Edit:  Nice fresh bottle courtesy of JRedmond who daddd up and brought one back from his vacation.  Aroma is incredible, but the flavor still doesnt live up to the nose.  Gave it another point for overall since its so fresh.

Poured a HUGE head that settled to a thinner but long lasting one. Lacing is apparent, although certainly not heavy. Good carbonation. Color is a cloudy orange/copper. Wow, this smells perfect for the warm day it is. Nose is lemon and orange and some spice. Taste is first lemon, orange/mango but with a great spicey bready malt and that rye backbone. Bitterness is very mild in the finish. So refreshing...it does NOT deteriorate as it warms. This is a pretty perfect balance for me. Sessionable? You bet. This is an amazing beer - great nose, so flavorful, and leaves you wanting more (and I DO)! How can you left-coasters sleep at night keeping this to yourselves!?

22 oz. bottle shared by foppa78 and the KC Beer Saints.  Thanks again, guys!  Its starting to look like you all shared more with me than vice-versa, so I might have to make a drive over to KC and make up for it.  Awesome to see them using the Sauvin Nelson hop; I actually spent a nice day in sunny Nelson, New Zealand and it is beautiful.  Anyway, from my little bit of notes: pours a cloudy gold color with a creamy off-white head.  Aroma of mellow oranges, maybe tangerines, with piney hops, and some nice floral and herbal notes to complement the caramel malt.  The flavor follows suit, for the most part.  Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a mouthfeel that falls somewhere between malty and juicy.  Great IPA.

22 oz bottle poured into a snifter.

A-Body is a quite hazy medium to dark golden amber hue. Pours with an approximately 2 finger foamy white head that eventually fades to 1/2 finger and has perfect retention from there. Little lacing is left behind in the glass.

S- Nose is VERY good. The emphasis and highlight is delightful juicy citrus and the rye comes through in the backbone very well. Another great smelling IPA.

T-Mild to moderate citrus is the highlight with a huge rye and herbal background. A small dose of pine comes through for the finish and adds to the increasing falvors of rye, herbal hops and citrus. A mild bitterness lingers-but the remaining citrus and mild pine flavors overshadow the rye bitterness. Interesting because the flavor is more bitter upfront and not really bitter at all at the end-the flavor progression is opposite of most brews.

P-Moderate tingly carbonation and a nice smooth, oily yet light to moderate weight hoppy body.

O-This is a good and quite interesting rye IPA. The mouthfeel and smell are great and the taste is above average. Its a little bit heavy on the rye for me without a big piny hop punch to counterbalance it. The citrus is a great touch-and I wish this were more present than the herbal punch. The herbal/rye combo overshadows the other hops trying to shine through. Still a great brew overall.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-21-2010 04:24:53

Bottle thanks to mrkrispy (BA)!Orange-gold with a thick white head. Nose and flavor are both quite muted, heavy grass and biscuit sweetness. Dry body, sweet malty finish. More appropriate as an APA, but even at that it would be light. Not sure where this one is going.

Came highly recommended by Sid and the folks at the Super Jr.  Poured very smoothly into my trappist glass, almost no head and very little carbonation.  Nose is full of all the good west coast IPA stuff: citrus, pine, hops, a bit yeasty in the vain of Pliny The Elder.  A semi translucent tangerine colored beer with a pinkish hue, a rosy glow if you will.  Initial hit to the palate is pretty average but the flavor is what carries Nelson.  The grapefruit is evident and the rye provides some character to go along with the sweet hops.  Nelsons a keeper.

22oz bottle from spry on BA - thansk Aeimit! Mellow yellow pour, with a faintly cloudy quality to it like pulped fruit had been added. A nice creamy head, as is customary for those awesome SD IPAs. Really delightful nose, like pushups and tangerine with resinous hops shot through. Mouthfeel is very nice, with a slight stickiness that seems to add to the appeal. Sharp flavors round out the overall sweet fruit tastes and its another delight from SD.

Fresh bomber. This one pours a very clear golden yellow color topped by a small, foamy off white head. The aroma is nice showing a mix between orange and lemon citrus, rye spices, and some hints of vinous white wine from the Nelson hops. The flavor follows suit with the orange and lemon bitterness mixing nicely with the spicy rye. The flavors are very fresh and crisp. The sweet toffee malt backbone offers balance to all the hops. I like the different fruity flavors the Nelson hops add to the beer. Medium bodied with balanced carbonation that leads to a dry, bitter finish. Really nice ipa from Alpine here.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2010 On draft at Hamiltons Tavern for 2nd Saturday: Pours a clear, yellowish golden color and topped with a one-finger white head that dissipates fairly quickly. A wonderful bouquet of pink grapefruit meat, citrus peel, fresh baby pine, wet grass, and chewy florals. Flavors of herbs, citrus peel, and caramel malt. Moderate carbonation, medium-bodied, oily throughout, and finishes with a delicate spicy feel which must be the rye. With more sips, that rye gets more apparent- it really sticks to the malted backing. Drinkability: Tasty fruity elements. My favorite Alpine IPA. Pairing; BBQ veggie burger, loaded with all the toppings. Rebuy: Yes. #386 on 10042010, DG.
Bomber bottle taste at Captain Lawrence. Great pour. Lots of head! ( just the way I like it!) fuity grapefruit hops and fantastic flavor. Find some!

22 oz bomber from padrefan98, thanks Jon. Poured a cloudy honey orange body  with a super bright white tightly packed large foamy head. Aroma is fruity with notes of peach, apricot, tropical fruit and citrus. Grains and cereal notes pick up the middle and the finish has an odd hint that I just cant place but also that I just dont care for. The body is perfect, mdium bodied that is crisp yet creamy and with just the right touch of carbonation. Flavor is a step up from the aroma with that odd aroma pleasantly gone. Notes of fresh hops, grass, citrus rind, grapefruit, tangerine, peach, apricot, bread. Very solid and man does Alpine have their finger on the pulse when it comes to IPAs.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2010 tap at the brewery as well as 2 subsequent bombers-Man, this is an IPA that i just love!  pours slightly cloudy golden hue-somewhat lite for an IPA with a small sudsy white head.  huge floral nose-tropical, pineapple, passionfruit, mangos.  Man, im digging this Nelson Saluvin hop bigtime!  flavors exhibit a huge hop wallop-lite pine, mostly mangos, pineapples, peaches, tangerine-just a huge citrus fruit basket.  palate is crisp and very nice on the mouthfeel-slightly slick and pillowy.  one of the best IPAs out there and this place makes many awesome ones!  I wish i could have this all the time.  subsequent bottles have exhibited a definate green grape note which is amazing!  i absolutely love this beer!  its all about hops, but thats not bad.

Bottle shared by ShareANevada.  Pours a hazy dark golden color with a medium sized fluffy white head.  The aroma ranks up there with the best; big citrus, orange, pineapples, resiny, and the rest of the west coast aromas that make them standout.  The flavor is juicy citrus, grapefruit, pineapple, resin, rye spiciness, dry in the finish.  The moderately sweet malt base does not quite balance the hops.  Medium bodied, not overly bitter, very drinkable.  This was a treat and I would welcome more.

Wow.

Tasted a bomber bottle from the esteemed South Bay Drugs & Liquor in Imperial Beach, CA.  Pours a hazy golden color with a small white head, and has a really great fresh citrus aroma (grapefruit) that lasts and, just as described on the label, hits you each time you lift your glass...downright enchanting.  Nelson is medium-bodied, and the citrus flavor carries over into the taste of the beer as well, but isnt overbearing at all; its more subtle and complemented by a slight grassy flavor (from the rye?) and a lovely, perfectly subdued bitterness from the hops.  Delicious; a wonderfully balanced and complex beer.  One of my favorite IPAs for sure.
Deep golden pour. Huge floral citrus, pine aroma. Nice malt body with just a touch of citrus hop bitterness. Wow, this is good.
Pours a cloudy tarnished yellow.  Hoppy nose with a lot of citrus and grapefruit in it.  Bitter but with a definite fruity element.  This is a good IPA.

Bottle, home.  Alpine night #2.  Another day, another fantastic IPA from Alpine.  Whereas Duet was a nearly perfect version of what I look for in an IPA, Nelson is unexpected but also world class.  This isnt my first encounter with Nelson Sauvin hops, but its definitely the best use of them that Ive tried.  The beer smells of orange rinds, wild lilacs, honeysuckle and sweet white grape juice.  The flavor is dry, bitter and spicy with rye.  The whole package works extremely well.  I have no real qualms with this beer, but I wouldnt mind if the rye was a bit stronger.  Id love to try an imperial version of this beer, so get on that Alpine.  The mouthfeel has a nice hop oiliness surrounding the duel between hop bite and rye spice.  Its an incredibly drinkable beer despite its unusual flavor profile.  Alpine has managed to make a combination of rye and Nelson Sauvin hops feel completely natural and Id love to spend a night with nothing but glasses of Nelson.
Wow, excellent brew. 22oz bomber into a goblet. Beautiful citrus aroma and flavors, very well balanced IPA

Big thanks to Stefanje for this one.  Pours golden with a big fluffy white head.  Dank aroma with herbal hops and a dirty spiciness which I guess must be the rye.  Light sweetness too.  Flavor is herbal, dank hops over caramel malts.  Rye is pretty apparent and adds a nice spicy malt component to the beer.  A light sweetness is apparent as well but kept in check by the bitter hops and spicy rye.  Good mouthfeel with nice carbonation and an orange peel finish.  Really badass brew here.

Bottle thanks to DuffManSW.  Slightly hazy straw colored pour with a big, loose white head that fades to lots of lacing.  Resiny hop aroma with lots of grapefruit, some floral pine and a vinous white grape note.  The malt component is dry, earthy and grainy with a moderate sweetness.  The flavor is white grapes, citrus, and toffee with some minty pine on the finish and a hint of butterscotch.  The body is creamy and full with lots of soft carbonation.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2012 Re-rate: on tap, fresh. Much better, huge fruit, massive sweet concoction with all the Nelson you want in a drinkable 7%.  

22 ounce bottle shared by footie, thanks man! Pours a clear copper color with a small bubbly white head. A nice sweet tropical fruit aroma, apricot, light grains. A nice flavor; a spicy concoction of rye and hops, fruity and spicy, alive full of vigor. A nice pairing. Easygoing.

(22oz bottle thanks to mar) Pours clear orange-yellow with good creamy head and excellent lacing. Nose of pineapple, florals, oranges, mango. Taste of oranges, pineapple, caramel, toastiness, and biscuit. Great citrusy/oily palate finish thats lightly spice as it warms. This is by a good margin, the best IPA Ive had to date.

A: Nelson pours a clear, light golden color with a very thin layer of white foam and great lacing.

S: These Alpine IPAs (Nelson and Duet) have an amazingly sweet, fruity hop character that I rarely see in IPAs. Tons of tropical and citrus fruits and not much in the way of malt, but a hint of spice from the rye.

T: The initial flavor is piney and bitter, with a ton of grapefruit. The back-end of the sip features a bit of malt, rye, and that great tropical fruit on the finish.

M: There is low carbonation, and a medium body.

D: This is a dangerously drinkable beer. The excellent fruity hops make this so delicious and leave you wanting more. But at 7.1%, you need to watch out, as a bomber of this can do some damage.

Bottle shared with friends at Stone Winter Storm.  Pours gold with a white lacing head.  Aroma is tons of grapefruit and orange with a nice spiciness.  Flavor is well balanced for an IPA, plenty of bitterness but not over the top.  Some grainy malts and lots of citrusy fruity hops.  Palate is medium and resinous with strong carbonation.

Bottle. Tannish-yellow body with a medium sized dense white head. Aroma is full of rye spice, grapefruit, orange, tropical fruits. Big fan of the Nelson Sauvin aroma. Flavor tends towards orange and tropical fruit sweetness, a bit of spice, a solid dry crackery malt foundation and nice amount of bitterness. Nice chunks of lacing remain on the glass. Wonderful stuff.

Bottle at Stone Bistro during winter storm 2010. Poured a yellow straw color with a nice thick head. Aroma was very sweet with orange and grapefruit. Taste was very well balanced with the use of rye malts. Very smooth and not bitter. Very good brew.

Good god this is deliciously intense. Ridiculous orange citrus hop profile. Big aroma and burst of orange flavor. Clear orange color. Touch of grapefruit bitterness. Smooth caramel malt to balance out the hops. Full bodied. Im still thinking about this beer weeks later.

Bottled...pours a clear golden with a white head...aroma is very sweet with a lot of citrus hops, mostly orange.... flavor is lots of citrus hops with a nice malty sweetness...I could drink this one all day.

Golden-orange pour with an thick, dense head. Aroma- tropical fruits (guava, passion fruit), citrus, peppery spiciness. Taste- hoppy, fruity, white grape, finishing with lots of peppery rye flavors. Medium-thin body.

Bomber via Stafanje the groovy.  They aint kidding about the everlasting grapefruitiness every time you lift your glass.   Crisp and sweet boy is in between moderate and full.  lacing is intricate and thins out at the top of glass but does not want to go away... I had to scrub the glass this morning of their remnants.  finish is muted and sweet with fringe citrus tones.  the yellowish island of head actually struck my teeth on the first quaff as if it were wishing to become hoppy bread.  I licked off my teeth and continued consuming this lovely brew.  Many more thanks to the Santee Connection.

Bottle thanks to WeeHeavySD.  The look is clear, has a whitish head, and is yellow golden in color.  The smell is spices, pine, caramel, and pepper especially white pepper.  The taste is spices, caramel, bitterness, and pepper.

Bottle. Poured hazy copper color with an average frothy white head that lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate to heavy grapefruit and earthy hop aroma. Medium to full body with a slick texture with soft carbonation. Moderate to heavy bitter flavor with a moderate to heavy bittersweet finish of medium to long duration. Very good brew.
Light amber pour with an extremely thick, solid head.  Super citrus aroma, almost plastic-y.  Flavor has lots of apricot and lime notes with medium hop bitterness.  Nice.
Pours golden with white head, aroma is full of spicy and citrusy hops.  Taste is lemon, mango, orange up front with the spiciness of the rye and a nice bitter after taste.  Excellent!

22oz. bomber.  Pours a hazy bright golden yellow with a large white head; great retention and lacing.  Aroma is tropical fruit goodness, with fresh mango, citrus, grapefruit and orange.  Flavor is nicely hoppy without going overboard, with more tropical fruits and a mild biscuit malt backbone.  A more subtle IPA flavor wise, but very well done.  Quite enjoyable and very drinkable!

22oz. bomber.  Very pale straw color with a very lacy layer of froth.  Crazy nose from the New Zealand hops that is heavily tropical with mango and papaya characteristics.  A trace of rye malt is also detectable in the aroma. The taste is also very fruity with a touch of sweet malt and a strong rye malt flavor.  A little bit of dough and bread flavor with a strange almost Belgian yeast note.  Excellent light mouthfeel with a slightly oily texture that showcases the hops well.  Finishes with a tropical fruit flourish and a very mild bitterness. The best of the rye malt IPAs Ive tried. Highly recommended if you can get your hands on some.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2014 Rerate:  pours a amber orange with a white head and decent lacing.  aroma is of grapefruit, tropical fruits, pine, and a sourness from the rye.  flavor is of tropical fruits, grapefruit, resiny pine, honey, and rye.  has a medium body with a creamy mouthfeel and a dry, crisp finish.  overall, a excellent IPA.
Bottle from Dave!  Pours orange in color with a small white head.  Tropical fruit aromas.  Tropical fruit flavors.  Finishes fruity with a mild bitterness.  A very very good IPA.

On tap @ brewery.  Hazy golden tangerine with a solid 1-finger eggshell head that left a ton of sticky lacing lining the glass.  Interesting brew with the most enjoyable use of Nelson Sauvin hops Ive tried.  The rye is subtle but present and adds a unique twist.  Tons of citrus, moderate pine, and just enough malt to make this one drink well.  Rye lingers a bit on the lips and palate.  Pretty damn good.

Bottle from South Bay.  Hazy gold color and pours with a thick fluffy off-white head.  Lacing coats the glass like glue.  Citrusy aroma; grapefruit, fruity zest, leaves.  Theres a real biscuity saazy type of flavor to this.  Very unique and interesting flavors.  Tropical fruity sweetness is complimented pretty nicely by a sharp bitter hop bite.  Herbal and oily with some orange peel and almond in there as well.  The use of this hop almost gives it a Belgian twist but  in a very unique way and not like those Belgian IPAs out there.  I enjoyed this beer.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2010 RE-RATE 6-25-10: Bomber.  Basically, a lot of what I said the first time I rated this, but giving MUCH more credit to the subtlety and balance of this brew. Its not like weak Arrogant Bastard, its a well-made IPA with great pine, rye, and resin taste and an even-handed finish.  Rating it higher on taste and overall this time. 

 Bottle shared with MrBunn.  Pours golden amber-orange, with minimal white head.  Aroma is strongly pine citrus.  Flavor and body/mouthfeel are like weak Arrogant Bastard, especially at the end where it turns a bit watery.  Still, a very solid offering, with excellent summertime drinking capacity.

Bomber.  Pours a nice golden orange with a sudsy head and smurftastic aromas of resin and pine, sharp citrus and a little tropical fruit.  Got to love the Nelson Sauvin.  Flavor bogs down a little in that the hops presence is there, but its a very sweet honey maltiness up front and the hops has a little bit of a soapy edge to it.  A nice resin and pine presence is ephemeral in the middle of the plot development and then the finish is a tropical fruit basket.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
Thanks to Exiled for sharing this bottle.

Pours a yellow straw color with a white head. The main components of the aroma are rye and peaches with some other fruit as well, a very pleasant and different smelling beer. The flavor is rye, grapefruit and a little bit of bitterness. No real alcohol is detectable. A unique beer with a medium-thin mouthfeel and good carbonation. Very drinkable.

Bottle courtesy of Smokepot23.  Poured a hazy orange color with a small off-white head.  Nose is caramel, with big pine and citrus notes.  Medium bodied with good carbonation.  Flavor is sweet caramel, pine, citrus, grass, and some tropical fruits.  Mild bitter finish.

The Nelson IPA is a murky, bread like ale, composed of dense and spicy notes. The head of the beer makes a small island of foam; thin as shaved ice. Nelsons flavor is robust, while sporting a smooth mouthfeel. A great companion to sip - or chug, depending on your preference - while engaging in conversations. Lots of hops bolt back and fourth in this complex IPA. Recommended.

( 22oz bottle, courtesy of WeeHeavySD )  Pours a murky golden orange body with a small white head.  Aroma of toffee, nuts, caramel popcorn, and light grapefruit.  Flavor of caramel malt, grass, grapefruit, toffee, and earthiness.

Courtesy of tpd975. This bomber pours clear deep gold with nice white head. The aroma is full of yummy hops of grapefruit mixing with white wine, tangelo, a touch of floral hops and some spice. The taste is bold with a pleasing mix of tangelo, grapefruit, slight white wine, some spicy hops and a touch of lemon acidity. Wow, plenty of tasty hops in this brewed being held up by a subtle backbone of malt sweetness.

Well, yes.  Hops, hops, and more hops.  Lots of grapefruit, lots of pine, lots of bitter.  Nice malty notes as well.  Well balanced for something this hopped.  Good head, good mouth, no longer distinctive ... the hops may be Nelson Sauvin, but they brew up like a great west coast IPA, and there are already plenty of those.

Pours a cloudy dark golden color with ripe banana hues when held to a light source and a 1.5 finger frothy, pillowy white head with good retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap.

Dank oily hop aroma with lots of dry earthy pine needle along with some sweet citrus notes, rye and subtle malt character. It smells like there is some incredibly fresh hops with a good bit of sweet citrus peel and grapefruit but the dry piny scent dominates.

Very well balanced dry, sweet and bitter medium body that is slightly earthy with a lot of uber fresh juicy hops. Lots of dry earthy pine up front that is quickly balanced by a nice citrusy lemon peel/grapefruit character, sweet rye malt and graham crackery malt presence. I was hoping that the rye would be more pronounced but it was a bit subtle providing nice balance. The ABV is excellently masked resulting in a complex, flavorful and dangerously drinkable IPA.
@Tampa Wkly Gathering @tpd975s-22oz bottle-pours a thin white head and hazy amber color.  Aroma is grapefruit hops.  Taste is lots of grapefruit/some pine hops, some light malt.

Served from a 22 oz bottle from OTM. The apperance is a slightly hazy pale gold with a full white head. The aromas flow from the bottle as soon as you pop the cap. A very dry raw hop aroma. The flavors are a hidden bitter hoppiness with a lot of rye bread flavors and grapefruit. A very dry mouth. Another fine IPA from Alpine!

Poured from bomber a nice hazy light golden hue, forms a craggly off white foamy head.  Aroma pungent of tropical fruits, pine resins, malts and ocean water.  Lacing evident as beer is gpwd down, overall sexy and extremely drinkable.  Superb IPA, Alpine does it again!
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text:
A:  Pours a very pale yellow with a tall pillow like head.  Okay retention and light lace.

S:  Nice bold grapefruit aromas, orange, and tropical fruit.  Aroma is very juice like.

T:  Wonderful grapefruit flavor.  Notes of green grass, and floral like perfume.

M:  Medium in body, nice carbonation.

Bottle from the Best Damn Beer Store in San Diego, with thanks to Sid the beer guy there for pointing this out to me. Clear gold body; medium white lacy head. Big expressive tropical fruit aroma, grapefruit, passionfruit, hop resins. Very very drinkable. Far from heavy, quite dry, and a lot of the non-bitter hop qualities come through. Signature powdery/perfumy impression of Nelson Sauvin. This dry perfumy character actually reminds me of Orval, of all things. This is up there with the best IPAs and double IPAs Ive tried. Think a single IPA version of Double Trouble.

bottle thanks to bhensonb.  poured light hazy orange with a white head.  aroma was nail polish remover, melted plastic, and upon warming the grapefruit started coming out.  flavor was a medicinal something or another.  once again once this started warming the flavor stood out.

Simply the best Rye-P.A. Ive ever had. Body is a nice dry rye body, hop aroma is the dankiest, stickiest pot youve ever smoked and the finish is clean. Despite this being rye, its incredibly balanced, and doesnt have too much bitterness to get in the way of the hop aromatics. Pours a copper hazy with thin white head. Despite the thinness of head, it leaves a very nice lacing design on the glass.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2013 Draft at the brewpub. Very light golden orange/yellowish color. Small head. Nose is fruity, perfume notes, light flowers, lavender/vanilla. Taste is super smooth and easy to drink. Hoppy but not really bitter.... grapefruit, mango, citrus, flowers, floral notes.... Damn this is tasty! Really light and crisp. Refreshing, I could drink this all day everyday and not get tired of it.
bottle thanks to weeheavysd.  cloudy gold with a white head.  grapefruity fresh hops and sticky esters.  great on the palate with a nice sticky grapefruit flavor and a clean finish.
Bottle courtesy of WeeHeavySD.  Hazy yellowish appearance. Fat hoppy smell. Very spicy aroma with hot sap. Flavor is dry taste with spices that turn earthy quickly. Flavored fairly well.
Bottle thanks to weeheavysd. Hazy brown pour. Aroma is citrus, simcoe, pine, grapefruit. Flavor is citrus, grapefruit, pine, grassy.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2010 Bomber poured into glass. Very light color of orange and yellow. Small head and HUGE aroma of fruit. The first sip was like a fruit cocktail of pear, white peach, pineapple and guava. Amazing flavor, remarkably clean and refreshing. Not overly bitter, just awesome balance. 
Re-rated July 27, 2010: Up from a 4.1 to a 4.7. This beer is incredible; so floral and fresh and flavors dancing all over my tongue. A fantastic IPA that really has its own thing; which Im assuming is the straight Nelson hops. I love it.

22 oz bottle.  Clear straw with a fluffy white head.  Nose is pine, orange, caramel and hints of spearmint.  Crisp medium body with foamy carb.  Taste is pineapple, grapefruit and pine.  Finishes with a bitter, spicy bite; slightly numbing.

Bottle courtesy of bret27. Pours a light gold color with a frothy off-white head. The lightness is actually enticing considering the darker hues of so many awful, oversweet crystal malt bomb IPAs. Aroma is just ridiculous. A huge wave of tropical fruits explodes from the glass. Peach syrup, tangerines, passionfruit, grapefruit, pineapple; I really cant stop smelling this. The taste is, thankfully, pretty much identical to the aroma, so much so that it was hard to tell when I had stopped inhaling and started imbibing. Fruit salad with a great resinous medium bitterness. Oh and I was so fixated on the fruitiness that I almost didnt notice the rye, which works to spice up (pun intended) the malt base, which would otherwise be imperceivable. Insanely smooth and drinkable. Just a fantastic IPA.

Thanks smokepot23 for sharing. Pours a soft pale yellow with a two finger creamy white head. The nose is pungent, citrusy, fruity, very resinous and skunky. Flavor shows citrus rind, spicy, skunky flavors, very resinous oily feel, aroma is a bit better than the flavor. Palate is spicy with a nice medium bitterness that quickly dissipates.
My favorite IPA of any kind and I have had all of the top 30 double and single IPAs.
BOMBER.  Pours an orange body with a white head.  Huge floral grassy citrus body with a fresh cut lawn shavings resemblance.  Hints of rye, grass, pine and a drying grapefruit.  An Awesome IPA.

Hazy golden color with a medium sized, white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of Nelsons, toasted malt, toffee, citrus, and pine.  Taste of grape, pine, citrus, toast, toffee malts, and a bitter finish.

Bottle shared thanks to warriorsoul. Pours a lightly hazy golden wiht a smaller bubbly white head.  Aroma of apricot, grapes, citrus, oranges, tangerines, this is exactly what the NS hops can do.  So great this beer is built to highlight the hops. Flavor of grapes, tangerines, bready malt, some rye spcies.  Hops featured for sure.
bottle courtesy of iawaherkeye, thanks man! very nice ipa from alpine, cant wait to try more from them! excellent display of this hoppy, quite a tasty brew!
smooth and fruity IPA.  the nelson hops comes through in full force.  mellow but still bitter.  pours a light yellow color.

Bottle courtesy of kbm. Pours a hazy yellow to amber with massive two finger foamy white head. Aroma is sweet and floral with notes of citrus, grapefruit, light pine, honey, floral hops. Flavor is sweet and floral with notes of citrus, grapefruit, pine caramel, honey, light spice. Generally medium body with a floral hop finish.

Bottle from Lone Hill.  Aroma is very plainly rye but with the subtle grapiness of the Nelson hops and general fruity flowers (slightly sour).  Color is a reddish brown but light.  Flavor is kinda ruined by the rye, IMO.  The hoppage is very smooth and fruity, but gets smacked right in the face by a bit too much rye.  Turns it grainy and standard.  For me, this hop varietal is good enough on its own.  Mikk Single Hop has it right.

Bomber from South Bay Drugs. Pours a light golden amber with a white head that mildly laces. Great mixed floral and fruit aromas. Medium body with firm carbonation. Flavor is floral with grapefruit. Finishes bitter and floral. Great ale.

22oz bomber, FRESH from south bay. pours a bright, clear, lighter shade of gold with a thin, fluffy white head and great lacing. aroma is outstanding with huge, fruity hop notes of white grapefruit, mango, apricot, and even a touch of berry with beautiful floral and spicy pine notes wafting from the glass as well. flavor is excellent as well with the massive fruity notes of grapefruit, peach, pineapple, tangelo, and pear jumping out front with the smooth, and slightly sugary rye malts and spicy pine resins filling in the back end and leaving a dry, crisp finish. palate is medium bodied, creamy, perfectly carbonated and almost wet on the tongue owing the great fruitiness. overall, this is a top tier IPA for sure.

Bottle. Oh yeah. This again is my type of IPA. Along the lines of Sculpin. This is also nice and tropical. Floral and spicy too. Great balance and extremely drinkable. Aroma is pretty full too. Great resiny hops and it has a nice full creamy body. Awesome.

22oz bomber poured into a tulip.

Pours a clear light golden amber with a big fluffy white head that hangs on for quite a while and leaves decent lacing.

The aroma is wonderful, with massive pithy grapefruit, floral pine and grass up front.  The rye spiciness is evident as well and it really makes this more original than most in the nose.

The taste seems to be a little less citrusy than the aroma.  There is some grapefruit up front, but the sweet malts in the backbone are much more evident than in the aroma and finish is very spicy with the rye and bitter with pine resin and pineapple.

The mouthfeel is medium bodied and well carbonated, but the rye makes it smoother than most IPAs and I think it adds to the feel overall.

This is another great IPA from Alpine, who has never disappointed me in this style.  They are clearly making some of the best IPAs out there and Im pumped theyre bottling more of them.  Highly recommended...obviously.

22oz bottle from southbay.  tasted side by side with alpine duet.... duet pours a reddish orange brown as compared to the more golden orange hued nelson.   both exhibited and medium soapy white head that quickly dissipated.... aroma consisted mostly of vibrant and bold tropical hops with hints of mango and papaya, almost seemed wet-hopped with how dank it was. very bright... flavors followed a similar path.  juicy and assertive tropical fruit hops, a little dank and green that almost seemed wet hopped which is awesome. bitterness doesnt come through until the finish.  this is one solid ipa.  better than duet imo but both are way above average.

Citric nose with some apricots.  Hazy medium gold in color with some carbonation and minimal head.  Wow!  Interesting white grape-like hop flavor is certainly there.  It combines with some grassiness, spicy rye and very little caramel.  Rather thin and finishes quickly.  Interesting beer.

22oz bomber, no date from Best Damn Beer Store.  Clear golden with a 1/2 finger white head,  pretty good retention.  Big fruity apricot, pineapple up front in the nose with quite a bit of sweet spicy rye behind.  There is also a light berry--strawberry?--note in there as well.  Flavor is much the same with all the wonderful fruity hoppiness and rye.  I loves me some rye.  Bitterness peaks at a 5 in the semi-dry finish.  Medium body with light to moderate smooth carbonation.  I love this beer.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: UPDATED: FEB 9, 2010 10/09: Pours slightly hazed and orange with a halo of lace-inducing head.  Big lump fruity nose with juicy notes of peach, apricot and mango.  Dry, mimosa-like fruity flavors but shit...the fruitiness in this thing is freaking crazy...long live nelson sauvin...mikellar didnt get this kind of fruitiness out in their single hop as far as a can remember.  The finish is dry yet juicy...stingingly wet, so to speak.  Plump and flavorful.8.4.8.4.16 (4.0) 02/10:  Boost a point for being significantly better than Duet and satisfying me when IPAs never seem to satisfy me as of late

growler  thanks riversideak!!  pours clear, light amber with faint white head; wow, killer nose of pineapple, fruity, bitter hops; texture is quite light and flavor doesnt match the strong nose; mildly fruit, orange peels, grassy hops with touch of buttery popcorn; dry, light and smooth; as I drink more I get some spicy hops and rye flavors

On tap @ blind lady. Orange yellow pour, hazy. Aroma of pungent citrus and pine, fresh as hell. Flavors of pine and citrus, ample bitterness followed with dry malt.
Excellent hop bomb.
Golden pour with a thick white head.  Spicy hoppy aroma.  Lots of fruit.  Hoppy flavor with a nice spicy rye twange to it.  Nice, crisp IPA.

Growler from RiversideAK, thanks Alex!  Juicy ripe mango and papaya explosive aroma.  Gold, short lived head.  Polarized here.  Starts very juicy, gets dank and musty.  Jagged.  Finishes gritty and completely opposite from where it began.  This doesnt really work with me, but its a very good beer with plenty of personality and uniqueness.

Huge pineapple nose, some pine, catbox,and citrus notes underneath. Golden pour, oily and resiny. Nice white frothy head. Lots pineapple, pine, cat box. Rye grain, spice in finish. Lingers for a while. Really drinkable, nose is better than than flavor, but this drinks very well.

growler. thanks, riverside! pours hazy burnished medium amber. creamy white head. gorgeous mango and apricot nose. creamy medium body. pronounced fruity notes on the mid palate. rye sourness mingles in, blending beautifully. tangy and oddly tart finish. long slightly tangy and resiny finish.

Tap at Toronado 22nd Anniversary.  Clear golden with a lasting white head.  Aroma is pale and rye malts, grassy/floral hops, and maybe even a little bit of the "wacky tobacky."  Flavor is pale malt, grain, great spicy rye, and fresh citrus/floral hops.  Body medium, palate crisp.  Really solid.

Alpine Nelson Rye IPA 8/8/09 (on tap, Blue Palms.  Blasphemy, I know, but this was better than Pure Hoppiness by a slim margin.  Aroma is lemon-lime, grapefruit, candy bubble-gum and fresh, fresh, fresh.  Flavor is a cleanly floral drink with a lemon wedge, pine, and bitter-spicy finish.  My goodness, that rye is used perfectly.  It sharpens the body, adding crispness to a beer that already is ridiculously citrus-hoppy.  More complexity than Pure Hoppiness, and one of my favorites on a night of amazing drinking.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2010 On tap at Obriens.  gold pour, white head.  Lots of fresh resinous hops in this.  Pine, citrus, a bit of sweet caramel, floral, and a bit of pepper spiciness.

Rerate:  Bottle. rye is most noticeable, citrus, piney hops, caramel malt, spicey hops.. mmm this is good.

Some of the best beers come direct from the brewery or brew pub, in this case Alpine Brewery and I am about to sup on Nelson, an IPA so fresh that he may have brought the hop fields with him. He poured a clear crystalline yellow with a small head and an aroma so big that I am transported to fields of blooming hops and green grass. Fresh has a new poster child. Pine needles, spruce trees, green grass wet with dew, and a bit of a bite at the back of my nose. Permeating his nose is an overwhelming sense of freshness and I am certainly not complaining. Lips wet with anticipation, my first quaff is clean, crisp, and bursting with vibrancy. Grass and pine needles tingle and prickle the top of my tongue before fading into a lingering crisp presence. Dew drops and green grass mingle with lemon in the middle of a light body which has a decent presence of effervescence. Wow. Fresh, clean, invigorating, and oh so hop-erific. Seeing as there was plenty in the growler to go around, I went for another small helping of Nelson before we had to part ways for good.


I finally get it. There is no IPA quite like a fresh IPA. Bottling abilities and technology is at an unprecedented level of quality and high standards, but it will never beat the real deal fresh from its source un-pasteurized and ready for immediate consumption. Brew on Alpine, brew on.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2009 Growler from the brewery on release day.   Gold with a lasting white head.   Super green, dank, spicy, grape, and mango hop aroma.   Awesome.   Smells like no other IPA that Ive had, yet is unquestionably one of the best hop aromas that Ive ever come across.   The flavor has a similar light toasty malt to their other IPAs, but with just a touch of rye spice.   The hop flavor is all there, but is not too bitter at all, just very dank, fruity, and juicy.   The body is on the light some with smooth carbonation.   I know that this is at the peak of freshness, but damn this is amazing.   Unique and just awesome all around.Rerate: I am beginning to see this less as an IPA, and more as a god-like nectar.   And out of the bottle!   The world is going mad.   I cant even quantify how intensely fruity and juicy the aroma is.   There is really nothing like it as far as I know, which is not much, but hey.   It was almost equal with sculpin when they were both out of the tap, but this blows sculpin away in their bottled forms.
Courtesy hopscotch.  Slightly dark straw color, thin off-white head.  Decent clean grassy hop aroma, mild biscuity malt background.  Very light hop taste, pretty muddy overall.  Decent.
Poured hazy yellow with a white head. Aroma of pine and lemon. Good IPA thats slamable.

On tap from DJBs. Clear golden , copper hues. White head. Earthy piney and hoppy aromas. Smooth mouthfeel. Solid tasty bitterness with a bit of sharp spiciness. Good balance and finish. Very nice for sure.

Sampler at the brewery.
pours clear golden, white head.
Aroma, super hoppy, sweet citrus.
Taste, citrus, New Zealand Nelson Sauvin hops that had for a not overly bitter mouthfeel, keeps a citrus like palate and pine, light notes of spices.
Great tasty IPA, just smooth while keeping the citrus presence, not much bitterness. This is pure goodness.
Stinky sharp IPA flavor on nose. Rich amber color. Did I mention it was stinky? Sharp sweet flavor. Fruity and hoppy

Had several times now, most recently at Toro SD.  Great stuff.  Rye in the current batch seemed a little more subdued but still huge hops, nice rich mouthfeel.  Long finish.  Depends on the mood but sometimes my #1 Alpine brew, Duet, or exponential trade off.  Solid.

Poured into a flute
Golden body with brown haze.
thick foam cap. retained and laced like mad.
Smelled very strong of pine and floral hops.
Body is almost silky, nice rye body up front, washes with a large amount of bittering hops. As balanced as you can get for something so hop forward.
Still crisp and light enough to be drank in a session. Guaranteed to hop bomb the toilet the next day if you do though.

From Growler. Pours a golden with medium white head. Lots of sticky lacing Aroma is full of floral notes .peach..  Taste is peachy with a spicy sweet kick. very smooth and very drinkable. This would be perfect in hot summer days.

CPLYFO 09.  Thanks to Hopscotch for sharing the Growler.   Pours a nice hazy blond with a thin white tacky sticky head and good lace.  Aroma is intensely hopped up tacky, resinous- seemed a bit like summit though- lots of pungent tropical and citrus-like fruits with hints of garlic- and I get almost no sauvignon blanc character in the aroma.  Flavor has a slight hint of white grapey mineral- character but it is dominated by citrus, pine resin and mango with a very nice light crackery and slightly sweet malt backbone to let the hops all the way through- good tacky resinous finish- and mostly bitter- Nice IPA!

Growler. Pours a clear amber-gold with a small white head. Big bitter aroma, wonderfully hoppy, with pine, grass, and grapefruit. Very bitter hops taste, with a lot of grapefruit and grass. Lingering bitterness. Awesome IPA.

Growler courtesy of WeeheavySD.  Pours gold/copper with a generous white head.  Smells initially of citrus and fresh melons before giving way to resin, perfume, soap, metallic hints, some spice, and some underlying sweetness.  Tastes of pepper, lightly bitter, and resiny with some spice and caramel on the finish.  I love this hop variety.

Courtesy hopscotch. Gold with a white head. Hops are big pine and citrus along with some grassy and earthy notes. Clean malt with a bit of spiciness from the rye. Medium body, balanced carbonation, dry finish. Very drinkable IPA with plenty of flavor, dig those nelson sauvin hops.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2009 Growler... C&PsLYFO Throwdown... Hazy golden ale with a small, creamy, white head. Decent retention. The nose is all about resiny, gooey, earthy lupulin and a lesser grain component - specifically rye. Medium-bodied with dancing carbonation. Bitter, but balanced. Crisp rye and tropical fruit. Snappy, dry finish. Thanks a million to WeeHeavySD for shipping this beauty of an IPA all the way from San Diego to Orlando!  Video = http://homepage.mac.com/maltajo/RATEBEER/iMovieThe

Growler, courtesy hopscotch.  Pours a mostly clear medium golden color with a foamy, off-white head.  Wet, spotty lacing marks the glass.  The nose shows a pretty ample citrus hop profile, with primarily orange blossom and lemony notes showing a top a light toffee and rye grain background.  Flavors are fresh, crisp and hoppy, with sharp lemon bitterness working nicely with the rye, which I find to be a sharp grain.  Lightly sweet toffee offers balance.  Medium bodied, semi-dry, and crisp on the palate, it drinks easy for 7%.  Very nice brew.
FRO Throwdown: Huge fresh hop smell. Citric and resiny. Bread and grapefruit flavors. Tropical fruits in these hops. Golden color.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2014 Bottle from the Otown throwdown.  Hopscotch on the hookup.  Bright yellow pour with a small whtie head.  Aroma of fresh papaya, mango, and grass.  Nice hops on the nose and some serious citrus hop bite on the tongue.  Malty, fruity and hoppy...yu!

Time for a re-rate! Vibrant, fresh, tropical, lightly bitter, citrus...simply a stunning beer.

Courtesy hopscotch.  Pours a lightly hazy gold with a small off white head.  Smells of dry hops, a little bread, with touches of spice andcitrus.  the flavor has a pretty crisp citrus touch to it, with a good amount of hop bitterness as well.  A little bit soapy in the finish, but still a very refrshing and tasty beverage.

Growler acquired in trade with WeeHeavySD. Poured a medium and slightly hazy golden color with a larger sized white head. Aromas of citrus, pine, tropical fruits, and rye. Tastes of citrus, pine, the same tropical fruitiness, rye, and toasty.

On tap at OBriens. Pours with a golden body, with a small, fading white head. Aroma of citrus hops, dank, rye spiciness, and caramel. Taste is tons and tons of citrus and pine hops with a touch of mango, a bit of rye spice as well. A very nice drinking IPA. Water like mouthfeel, light carbonation.
Growler courtesy Hopscotch.   Pours a warm glden color. Aroma is spicy and resinous, with some notes of mango.   Rye flavour comes through, nice hop bit on the  finish.  solid.

Very fruity, hoppy aroma, with secondary smell of flowers reminiscent of an aromatic white wine.  Pleasantly, strongly bitter without being harsh. Nice, bready, lightly honeyed malt base that supports, but does not really balance the hops.  Thats ok because this beer is about those fruity, tangerine, lime hop aromas.  Very, very good, refreshing, flavorful, powerful.

On draft at Toronado, San Diego.  Pours a clear yellow-orange with minimal head and little carbonation.  Nose full of grapefruit and grass.  The flavor comes on bitter and strong with pine and grapefruit.  The finish has a noticeably toasty flavor which must be the rye.  A refreshing and original IPA.

A- Clear golden orange hue, minimal head that congregates to a cluster of foam in the center, sticky lacing
S- HUGE rye malts and bread malts, subtle citrus and grass hops
T- Taste is dominated by rye malts to an overwhelming extent (almost like eating a deli sandwich), opens up to some grass and pine hops, finishes with a rye bread aftertaste
M- Medium-bodied, oily texture, highly carbonated
D- This is the most rye-heavy beer Ive ever tasted, definitely an acquired taste that loses points for me personally (not a big fan of rye bread), the dominating rye appears off-balance and limits overall drinkability

On cask on the last night of existence for the Liars Club.  Awesome fruity aromas off this hazy orange ale with a small tight head.  Mango, Apricot, Pinapple, tangerine.  More of the same on the flavors with a nice sweet maltiness as well.  Grassy hops took over for the fruit in the finish.  Very smooth on cask.  Good stuff.

On tap at Obriens.  Clear gold in color with a thin to small off white head.  Clear.  Aroma was strong and pungent.  Citrus, orange, flowers, with hints of caramel, honey and BO.  Flavor was stinky as others have mentioned, as there was a good amount of BO like flavor.  Also a solid amount of citrus, grass and herbs.  Some fruit, but not much balance in this one.  Also, I am not too big of a fan of this hop varietal.

Tasted at AlohaCs party.  Thanks to IronChefScott (I think).  Poured from Growler.  Stinky sharp IPA flavor on nose.  Rich amber color.  Did I mention it was stinky?  Sharp sweet flavor.  Fruity and hoppy.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2011 Re-rate: 650 ml bottle from Bev4less. Pours a cloudy yellow color with a fine white head that has good retention and some lacing. The aroma is strong with grapefruit and green hops. The flavor is overtly fruity with mixed citrus, rye and a good biter hop bite. There is also a chlorophyll fresh hop note in the flavor. The mouthfeel is silky smooth. The finish is long with lingering nelson hops.Overall: A solid IPA but different than I remember the draft version. Since bottling this has become my go everyday IPA, great stuff.
Rerate again on 15 jan 11- tap at the brewpub - still good as ever.

Sampled on 10/18/07, courtesy of a growler from kmweaver. Clear BRIGHT yellow/gold with a white head. Extremely sunny, bold, citrusy tropical fruit hop nose. The malt base is simple to showcase the hops on this one. Slightly catty (I kinda like that) with notes of tropical fruits, lemon and citrus. Pretty dry/attenuated and crisp. Not much sweetness. Smooth, yet ample bitterness. Medium bodied, smooth texture and moderate carbonation. Loved it.

On-tap at Churchills today. Pours a somewhat dark yellow color, not too dark but darker. Crispy white head, thin spider-web lace. Light, crispy hop scent, pine for sure, some sweetness in the background. Tastes light and crispy piney, slightly grassy, light. Mouthfeel is thin with good carbonation.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2009 On tap @ the brewery.  Different......good!  Off the beaten path of your standard IPA.  Nose was sweet and citrusy with a funky earthy undertone. That New Zea land hop brings something extra to this IPA.
Taste from friends growler.  Golden yellow with a fizzy white head.  Strong pine and citrus aroma.  Big pine-apple taste, sweet fruit juice flavor, pine, and a decent bitter bite.

Growler courtesy of kmweaver. Clear light golden/pale body with a small off-white head. The nose is hoppy with cat urine, grapefruit, tangerine and light garlic. The flavor is lightly sweet, lightly bitter with pine, grapefruit, cotton candy, onion and tangerine. Medium body is soft with moderate carbonation.

Tap @ OBriens.  Poured a hazy gold color with a medium sized white head.  Big fresh citrus and pine hop aroma.  Strong and forward.  The flavor had some grapefruit hop notes mixed with malt.  A let down compared to the aroma.  Light CO2.

Clear gold with a medium white head.  Pine, resin bomb in the nose with grass and grapefruit.  More resin and pine in the flavor, with the citrus taking a back seat.  Sharp rye taste in the back with minerals and a vinuous bite.  Excellent IPA.

Draft. Golden beer with an off-white head. Very fruity (summer/tropical) aroma. Summer/tropical fruit flavor (lychees?) with malt and earthy spice backing. medium body. Lingering fruit with some pine/earthiness and spice.

Handbottled. Thanks to cbkschubert for the handbottle. Poured a nice golden body with thin head. Aroma was so nice! Beautiful citrus aroma that reminded me of a cara cara navel. Flavor had a nice little sugary citrus to it, sweet caramel malt and well balanced. Easy sipping IPA and one of the best that I ever had.
Very Hoppy brew.  A ton of pine and citrus in the nose.  A little sweetness that leads to huge hop flavor.
Growler courtesy of wethrel. Aroma of grass, pine, citrus, and hops. Solid IPA flavors of pine, citrus, and hops. Very drinkable.

12oz. hand bottle from cbkschubert. Grapefriut lights up the nose for aroma. Cooper body with white head mild lacing. Flavor is like a thicker sugar grapefruit cocktail bomb. Fresh citrus ligers on the palate for couple of hours after consuming this one. Good Brew thanks Craig.

Aroma: huge sweet grapefruit aroma
Flavor: sweet grapefruit flavor, light bitterness adds balance but stays out of the way of the hops, crystal sweetness supports the hops

beer good.

big fruity character, lots of the orange and tangerine, 

Aroma: 8/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 16/20

Growler, courtesy of wetherel.  Thanks, John!  Pours a clear, bright honey-golden color; thin white head with great fine-bubbled lacing.  Dank, resiny and oily floral hops in the aroma; clean, slightly herbal, and excellent density.  The taste is a bit of a letdown: some cattyiness and gooseberries (dissipate quickly); very herbal  and resiny hop character, but not as compelling and oily as the aroma; nice crisp carbonation with some passion fruit and citrus at mid-palate.  Medium, minerals and passion fruit in the finish; resiny and oily again at the end.

(10/18/07, growler, thanks kmweaver) Off-white head atop hazy apple juice body.  Aroma is medium sweet, pine/spruce, mango, some caramel.  Taste is medium sweet, pine/spruce, mango/peach.  Light-medium body, the flavor doesnt linger.

Appearance: Pours a translucent golden body with a small, white head.

Smell: I must admit, I enjoyed the aroma far more than I have enjoyed anything else that is, or has ever been, placed in front of my nose. Very aromatic aroma of juicy oranges and pinapples, freshly cut grass, and what reminds me of either minced garlic or shallots. 

Taste: Light, fleeting malt flavor and sweetness upfront before a bright burst of juicy hop flavors, zesty orange rind and pineapple rings. Full notes of white grapes and garlic (or is it shallots). Hint of damp grass. All in all, theres only a very reasonable amount of bitterness. Finishes decidedly crisp.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: Its really great smelling stuff! I had to be restrained from pouring out the growler onto myself so I could continue to smell this beer for days and days to come.

Growler thanks to Omar and Ken.  The nose on this beer is downright strange, with confusing notes of mint, garlic, basil, lemon juice, sweaty BO hop oils and some stewed grains as well.  More of a pine needle presence tasted, with less of the sweaty unire and garlic notes, but they are still present, just more subdued.  Finishes with zesty lemon and honey hop notes, but theres also some moth ball and chlorine notes.  Interesting but too confusing,

Growler thanks to wetherel: Pours a transparent bright bronze golden with a stringy-lacing white head.  Fresh resiny piny and grapey hop nose has a good pale malty presence.  Starts lightly malty sweet having a huge citrusy flavor hop profile toward a crisp bittersweet, fresh hoppy finish.  A nice, very drinkable IPA.
Pours a light copper color with a white head.  Aroma is tons of floral, citrus hops.  Flavor is light caramel with a long bitter hop finish.

Growler courtesy of my man, Naven.  A very interesting brew.  Grassy, piney, slightly floral and citrusy w/ a earthy, UK-type hop presence as well.  Definitely some winey characteristics evident.  Dont know that Ive ever sampled a brew w/ Nelson hops before, so this was a treat.  Very good, but very interesting and a very different version of a West Coast IPA..

Poured from a growler.  Golden yellow and fairly translucent.  Unique aroma with an abundance both of interesting and off-putting moments; mango, white grape, salt, and leafy green spices are enveloped with time, plainly, into garlic toast.  Strange.  Flavor is similarly pungent and lightly spicy.  Basil leaves, crackers, old orange juice, and sweet whole garlic clove, mingled with restrained bitterness toward the finish.  Medium bodied, with lively carbonation.  Clean finish with lightly fruity and earthy tones.  Leaves an astonishingly and at times bewilderingly unique impression; in any case, this is a sudden and cheerfully revealed surprise in the arena of hoppy pale ales.  Thanks for sharing, Ken!

Growler: Pours a clear golden with minimal ivory head. Wonderful aroma of pine and lot s of citrus.The flavor is grapefruit driven but it is a combination of regular and pink. The palate is wll balanced and crisp. This is an excellent albeit different IPA.

Had a sample at the brewery, while picking up some growlers.  Excellent hop aroma.  Big super creamy microbubble white head.  Pale hazy yellow color.  Despite the big grapefruit hop aroma, the bitterness is mild.  Great beer.

On tap at Downtown Johnny Browns. This hazy yellow ale poured with a thin off-white head. This is a very hoppy brew, but the hop taste is quite mellow and unusual. There is a hint of citrus and some herbal qualities. Overall, a very pleasant drink.

I have been waiting to sample a beer made with Nelson Savin since they first hit the market.  Thanks to cbkschubert, I finally have the opportunity.  Lightly hazy, it even has some floaties from the growler, the beer is a light, copper color and it is topped by a ring of wispy, light tan colored froth.  The aroma is quite distinct, certainly hoppy, but not as I have ever smelled before.  It is quite herbal, with a note reminiscent of garlic chives, some musky hemp notes, and an almost woody grass-like note that can be quite pronounced at times.  There is a fruitiness from the hops too, and with all of the herbal focus, it is not too far of a stretch to say this is like Sauvignon Blanc.  It even has a touch of cattiness to it as well as notes of unripe grapes, lime and even some grapefruit if you really dig for it.

Very weird flavors here; certainly quite distinct in its hop character.  The hops contribute a definite catty note to the flavor that almost leans towards cat litter (though not nearly as bad as that sounds).  Strongly herbal hop notes contribute flavors of pine tar, woody-rosemary, oil-laden hemp seed notes, basil and something that is quite, distinctly, reminiscent of a herbaceous flavor that I just cant quite put my finger on, but is so apparent that I cant figure out why I cant put a name to it.  The beer is fairly light on the palate, and definitely is perceived as being quite dry.  While the herbal notes seem to dominate, there are significant fruit-like flavors contributed by the hops as well; flavors of slightly acidic, under-ripe, green grapes, kefir lime leaf, star-fruit, and a tart citrus character mix in, and somewhat mitigate the herbal notes.  As to the malt notes, well this is definitely an IPA, and they only play a supporting role here; just barely noticeable under all of the hop influence.  The bitterness is not over the top here; it is at a nice, contributing level though and helps to clean up the finish.

This is certainly a fascinating hop, it is quite different from any other hop variety that I have direct experience with.  Very interesting, and very tasty, I definitely could do with more of this beer.  I have a feeling though that these flavors would get old if I encountered them at such levels on a more regular basis.  The hop character (both the aroma & flavor) is so musky; it is makes me think of the essential oils of a mix of herbs.  I am not sure if it quite works in the IPA format, but could definitely see using it in some of the lighter colored Belgian-styled beers.  Definitely well worth it though, and I am still quite exited to use this hop in my own brewing.

On cask at OBriens. I went specifically for this brew, waited 10 minutes for the busy bar keeps to put it on. Thats ok, worth the wait. Very hazy yellowish amber with lots of floaties. I wasnt sure if this is typical of a cask pour, or was it because it was the first pour. Didnt matter as it didnt affect the taste. Wow, grapefruit, citrus, pine, a little grass, but nothing overpowering. Very drinkable. Deffinetly surprising, considering some other brews like Exponential, and Pure Hoppiness are put out by this brewery. I really think Alpine is on to something with these Nelson Sauvin Hops. Keep it up guys, and get this in to a bottle. A great IPA.

A growler from Bartzilla; which might explain why on pour, this looks exactly like urine, Bartzillas urine.  If not for the 1/2 inch white head, I would have thought it was a practical joke.  Even if it was Bartzillas piss, his piss is one of the best IPAs around.  The aroma is somewhat weak; having grapefruit, yeast, malt, and a touch of pine.  Flavor, very citrusy with hints of pine.  The finish is tart and crisp.  I did think that overall there was a watery taste and feel, as if it could be stronger.  Maybe it was the relatively low alcohol content; Im not sure.  Overall, this is one solid IPA that I wish was available in Minnesota so I could stock my fridge full of growlers.

from a growler provided by WeeHeavySD.  light in color with minal head, but lots of aroma.  Strong pine and citrusy. Flavor is clean bitter grapefruit with a bit of grapiness. finish is clean and crsip. very unique, very good IPA.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2007 draft @ obriens - this was as unique and one of a kind IPA as ive ever tasted. the aroma, the taste...all unique. the flavor i got from these hops was all grape leaves. reminded me of the stuffed grape leaves you might get at a mediterranean restaurant. lemon acidity with the grape leaf flavor. not for everyone, but i love interesting experiemental beers...and if i could get more of this...i would drink a ton of it.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2012 Ive sample this beer innumerable times at the brewery in good little ol Alpine. A masterful creation, one of the better Nelson Sauvin IPAs on my tick list. Rye malt adds a very unique character to this beer. Always delicious, crisp and refreshing. Ranks right up there in my book with Duet and Pure Hoppiness. Hats off to the guys at Alpine.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2009 On draft at the brewery and around SD. . .Really great IPA!!!  The aroma is incredible and is its best quality, one of the best ive experienced for an IPA.  It reaks of fresh cut pine...the rye adds a unique quality in the background of the finish too, which is very crisp and refreshing. perfectly balanced brew...if you can find it on draft, its a must try...  awesome awesome beer, cant wait for the growler.  I would seek this one out

Citrusy, grapefruit and orange.  Oily, delicious, piney hop taste.  Light-orange color.  Very good carbonation, lacework.  Would prefer slightly higher alcohol and malt influence.  But overall, excellent, fruity IPA.  Will try again in a month, seems young.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2007 Growler shared with Naven and Bartzilla.  This is my new favorite IPA, Barzilla describes it as Donald Duck Orange Juice.  It pours brght light amberish yellow, with a nice head.  The nose is citrusy and bright.  The taste is damn good orange grapefruit and just damn goodness all rolled into one.  This is a stellar IPA.  I would drink this every day if I could.
Tap @ Bistros 9th Annual IPA Festival 8/12/06.   Light golden hazed color with a white head.  A strong citrus (orange) and clove flavor and aroma with fresh cut grass in the finish.
Draft, murky light gold color, almost wit colored.  Orange and grapefruit aromas.   Slightly oniony.  Very bitter with a fuel note.  Hop forward with little malt.

Hand-bottled sample.  Hazy orange body.  Smells great!  The tart part of corn silage, orange slice (pop), and some resinous pine.  More orange slice in the flavor - orange rind, citric bitterness and piney sap over some caramelly biscuit malt.  Enjoyably assertive in the hopping.  Great bottling job!

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2008 Bottle was handbottled from a growler by cbkschubert. Thanks Craig!  The beer pours to a hazy glowing yellow gold body with a rich creamy white head.  The aroma is simply phenomenal.  Lots of pineapple, white grapes, peaches, sweet juicy simcoe and cascade hops.  The flavor is winey, white grapes, lemons, pine hops, sweet and juicy.  The palate is rich, coating, good.

Clear, slightly dusted gold body. Not much head, just a few big bubbles. Hop soaked peach juice aroma. Quite nice, though, not a whole lot else in it. Flavor is light, but good. Wet grassy hops with some pleasant candied citrus. Pretty good.

hand bottled from a growler.. Thanks to Blake for sharing.  Slightly cloudy off amber golden color w/ slow rising visable carbonation and a nice white frothy head w/ some lacing.  Amazing aroma.. simply amazing!  Hugly citrus hops grapefruit, and passionfruit, and bitter green grapes w/ some full malts as well.  Palate is full well coated and lightly oily.  Flavor is a let down from the aroma but still very good.  A well sweetened malt over a light grape, passionfruit, pinnapple type of flavor.  A very very good IPA.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2009 Bottle was handbottled from a growler by cbkschubert, Thanks, Craig! Nose was nicely hoppy with a small amount of citrus; Hazy yellow with a tiny white head, (probably due to hand-bottling two weeks before), wish I could have had it fresh! Flavor was hoppy with the bitterness lasting into the finish. 7/3/7/3/15 3.5 9/16/06
Bomber shared by Iowaherkeye. 10/09 Nose was ivy, ivy, and more ivy; lots of Simcoe hops! Awesome nose! Clear gold with a medium white head. Flavor nicely hoppy bitterness with a litle caramel sweetness. Finish bitter.

(HAND BOTTLED SAMPLE BY WAY OF IRISHBOY)murky off yellow with no head.nice pine hop aroma with some lemon floating around in the back.flavor was much of the same.i think the sample was flat due to the hand bottling but it was still pretty tasty.

Growler fill from Alpine Beer Co. - Pours a slightly hazy light golden color with a good size white head.  Lots of lacing.  Aroma is big time grapefruit and mandarian orange.   Has a nice sweet grapefruit flavor.  Not very bitter.  Medium body.  An excellent beer.  Glad I was able to get some before they ran out that afternoon.

Draft at OBriens.  Arrived in the glass a cloudy orangey amber color with a moderate, fluffy off-white head that left some lacing.  Aroma is dominated by hops. citrus abounds, along with lightly floral and even vinuous characteristics, with subltley sweet malt notes to balance.  Flavor is fruity and hoppy, my initial impression was of orange and grapefruit juice, continues with fruity malt flavors and of course is most prominent of hops, again lots of citrus and hints of pine.  Nice smooth medium body, gentle carbonation.  This beer is a winner for any hophead and a joy to experience.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2006 Sampler at the Brewery. I got a growler of this fine IPA. Pours a hazy golden with nice head. Aromas of Malts and Passion fruit lots of it...Very citrusy with hints of grapefruit, orange peel, and parmesan cheese.  For some reason it was exploding flavors in my mouth at the begining and then it got kinda light. Very smooth body and extremly drinkable despite the 7% abv. They rye was found only at the finish. Above average IPA, i could drink it all night.

Often, we hear people talk about the "citrus" flavor of their beer.  Sometimes, people refer to a grapefruit taste.  Well, never in my life have I tasted a beer that tasted so citrusy as this one.   Its quite amazing, but this beer almost tastes like a glass of grapefruit juice.  Looks like a glass of unfiltered orange juice.  Cannot believe this is over 7%, as I could chug this all day long.  The mouthfeel is light and refreshing, without the typical syrupy sweetness of most IPAs.   This tastes so friggen fresh.  I cannot really explain it, but its certainly a winner.  Looks great, smells great, tastes divine.  Bravo.

Wow.  This is my new favorite by the kind folks at Alpine.  Sampled at the brewery then promptly filled the growler and now I am promptly drinking it while my puny beer cooks on the stove.  This has a very unique flavor.  Almost fruity when it hits your mouth then a blast of these delicious Nelson hops and a wonderfully dry rye finish.  Dear Alpine Brewery:  Please keep this in rotation.  Please bottle it.  Please convince Adams Avenue Liquor to carry this.  Something.  Anything.  Just keep letting me have access to this.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2006 Tap, OBriens. Pours a hazy yellow orange color. Aroma is piney and bitter. Smells kind of like a garage for some reason. Very bitter and hoppy. Most noticable rye brew I have had to date. Reminds me a little too much of rye bread, pretty good still.

Pours with a cloudy golden body topped by a medium thick head with some lacing.  Its slightly sweet and citrusy with underlying notes of pineapple to start, then turns bitter with notes of pine, rye and lemon.  Medium bodied, dry and slightly warming.
